body: how about removing it (i.e., not overwriting) from both _paramIndexMap and _inputs?

1) I will go ahead and remove the parse warnings to standard output in DMLScript, the current MLContext, and the JMLC Connection if that's how you think it should be done. However, note that if log4j is not set up, the user will fail to see these important messages. In the new MLContext, this information shall potentially be handled differently so that Notebook users can see this information on the Notebook page rather than in a console, since it's quite possible a Notebook user will never see anything going to a console (such as log warnings).
2) I don't think 1 potential output to standard output will clog the stdout queue. From a usability standpoint, I would be sad if there was a warning regarding my DML script and SystemML didn't tell me about it in a clear manner. This information is still being logged as log.warn()
3) Since castAsScalar was a mistake, I assumed the CAST_AS_\* was a mistake. I will change the AS_\* names back to the legacy names.
4) I'm sorry, I don't understand. For raiseValidateError, the flag is still there but renamed from 'conditional' to 'doWarning', since without looking at the implementation of the method, I previously had no idea what 'conditional' means. 'doWarning' is clearer WRT what this flag is doing, and the new version has an accompanying javadoc description (@param doWarning if {@code true}, display log warning message. Otherwise, the message (and optional error code) will be thrown as a LanguageException)
I think updating the internal casting operations to `AS_*` would provide a cleaner mapping from the language representation (`as.*`) to the internal compiler representation (`AS_*`).
Agreed, splitting this up would definitely facilitate easier review and discussion. :)

ad 3) well, the issue with castAsScalar was that we did not follow R's convention for these kinds of casts - internally, however, the cast prefix was very appropriate. Anyway, I don't have a strong opinion here - if the majority of people preferes the AS prefix that's fine too.
ad 4) I understand why you made that change - the only reason why I would prefer to call the flag 'conditional' is that it represents a slightly different contract: with a flag like 'doWarning' the implementation has no choice but to raise a warning instead of a exception. With 'conditional' callers just report the context and it's up to the implementation to raise an exception or warning.

3) I'll change back to CAST_AS_*, but if more developers like @dusenberrymw and myself would prefer a closer match to the DML keywords, we can do a JIRA to change at all levels (hops (Hop.OpOp1, etc), lops (such as UnaryCP.OperationTypes, etc), ...).
4) I'll change back to 'conditional' but keep the javadoc comment so new developers don't have to look at the method implementation to see what's going on

sounds good - I appreciate it @deroneriksson. 

Btw, with regard to logging, we should think about creating a lean wrapper where all logging goes through which would allow us to quickly switch between logging and stdout (potentially depending on the api from where SystemML is called.)

@mboehm7 - In the test cases, to check the value of a variable from a DML script, we spit out the value into a file and examine it. Would it be a good idea to have the "execute" method return the ExecutionContext object, so that the variables can be examined post-mortem.

To make sure that a variable is not optimized away, we could potentially force a `write()` on it and then rewrite it using something like the [`RewriteRemovePersistentReadWrite`](https://github.com/nakul02/incubator-systemml/blob/master/src/main/java/org/apache/sysml/hops/rewrite/RewriteRemovePersistentReadWrite.java), much like how it is done in [`MLContext`](https://github.com/nakul02/incubator-systemml/blob/master/src/main/java/org/apache/sysml/api/MLContext.java#L1334)?

Well, let's stick to the normal process of read/write for tests as we want to test on level of entire dml scripts without potential for introducing issues by custom input-output handling. Note that for text input/output, the read/write actually is not the bottleneck but the parsing from text to binary and vice versa.
@mboehm7 Created a removeInput method in DataOp which is called from RewriteRemovePersistentReadWrite. Also created some basic scalar input tests for JMLC.

@mboehm7 @dusenberrymw @bertholdreinwald We have following options here:
1. Merge this PR with existing test-cases and figure out why the results of R code is not matching with CuDNN's result. Then update the corresponding test-cases with R checks accordingly.
2. Merge this PR with existing test-cases and ask for vote in the mailing list for adding Python dependency in our build environment. Once the vote is approved, then update the corresponding test-cases with Python checks accordingly.
3. Wait until we debug our R scripts (which we will have to write for conv2d_backward_, maxpooling, maxpooling_backward_), add R testcases and then merge this PR.
4. Wait until the vote for Python packages is approved and then add Python testcases into this PR and merge this PR.

I think the second option is the best because it allows us to keep making progress on performance improvement. Also, comparing our code with an external package is the right way to test our built-in functions.
before we discuss merging this PR let's get the code and tests in shape first - I'll provide comments soon.

thanks @niketanpansare for the initial prototype - here are a couple of comments to help improve the implementation:

1) Hop: Why do we need a new hop for these kinds of operations - isn't the semantic of various operations covered by ReorgOp and ParamBuiltinOp?

2) Pooling parameters: It would be good to support the general case of variables here instead of assuming that every parameter is given as a constant.

3) Size propagation: The current size propagation needs a rework. First, it always assumes entire 
dense  outputs which incorrectly propagates into subsequent operations. Second, there is no overwrite with unknown values which renders it incorrect in special cases of dynamic recompilation.

4) Validation: Please move any semantic validation out of the parser (DmlSyntacticValidator) and into the actual validate. 

5) Buffer pool: CacheableData is completely generic and should not have any references to MatrixBlock or FrameBlock, please move the reuse handling into MatrixObject or ExecutionContext.

6) Reuse allocated arrays: The current reuse of allocated arrays has two major problems: (1) it is not thread-safe, and (2) it creates incorrect results for operations that assume
zero-initialized outputs and accordingly don't overwrite each cell. Please add TODOs to fix that. 

7) Multi-threading - integration: Please integrate the decision on multi-threading into hops, lops, and runtime instructions. Note that the Hop should implement MultithreadedHop and requires treatment in the parfor optimizer - otherwise  the instruction would not be aware of the surrounding parfor parallelism.

8) Multi-threading - error handling: Currently, there is no error handling on multi-threaded operations, which means issues would lead to silent errors and hence potentially incorrect results. Please, explicitly call a get on each future. 

9) Block operations: Why are the individual operations directly implemented in the instructions? Please move to MatrixBlock and potentially create a LibMatrixDNN to groups these operations together.

10) Sparse operations: Currently, sparse operations would suffer an unnecessarily bad asympotic behavior as we access each cell, and each cell requires a binary search to find the value. It would be great to support both dense and sparse if these operations might be used by other usecases than pure dense inputs.

11) Distributed operations: how hard would it be to add the distributed operations for Spark/MR too? If infeasible, please add least add some comments into the reprective Hop as to why
these operations are not added.

12) Statistics: Please only maintain statistics whenever you -stats is enabled as the System.nanoTime and atomic counters can be an actual bottleneck. Also please, remove them from
MatrixBlock to ensure they are not unnecessarily called on distributed operations. Also the new counters need to be reset on Statistics.reset.

13) Tests: I would really appreciate to have the R scripts for tests as the unrolled expected results are really had to maintain and extend. In the worst case, let use at least provide these fixed expected results as CSV files. 

14) Codestyle: First, please move all class members to the top of the class. Second, please try to merge predicates to reduce levels of indentation (e.g., DataExpression.getMatrixParametersForTensorFn). Third, please remove the redundant opcode checks from the CP instruction. Fourth, remove commented stdout debug output. Fifth, don't use all capital names for non-constants (NON_ZEROED_DOUBLE_ARR, which is a map).

Thanks @mboehm7  for your comments :)

(1) I think having a separate Op for class of tensor-related functions/instructions (such as im2col, reshape_col, rotate_180, maxpooling, maxpooling_backward, direct_conv2d, ...) is extremely useful. I don't think all of these operations qualify as Reorg as some of them do more than simple reorg, for example: col2im. Also, these operations are fairly specific to tensor to be grouped as seperate Op rather than have them under ParameterizedOp. Also, just like AggregateBinaryOp, this Op can qualify for fusing/meta-optimization. For example: http://benanne.github.io/2014/12/09/theano-metaopt.html
(2) Pooling parameters: Can you please point me to the part where I assume every parameter is a constant ? If so, it is definitely a bug and will correct it.
(3) Yes, the output of ConvolutionCP instructions is always in dense format. We can revisit this assumption later. I can work on fixing overwriting of unknown values.
(4) There is no semantic validation in DmlSyntacticValidator. Since SystemML doesnot support list, all we do in DmlSyntacticValidator is unfold the list.
(5) Done.
(6) a. Converted  non_zeroed_double_arr to ConcurrentHashMap for thread-safety of put and remove. b. If the caller calls the method "public void allocateDenseBlock(boolean clearNNZ, boolean zeroOut)" incorrectly (i.e. allocateDenseBlock(..., false) when the operation requires allocateDenseBlock(..., true)) then and then only it will produce incorrect results. 
(7/8) Will add the multi-threading in the next commit.
(9) Will create LibMatrixDNN in the next commit. 
(10/11) I think we should optimize "Sparse operations" and "Distributed operations" in subsequent PR once we are happy with the performance of single node Lenet script on dense MNIST dataset. I have added respective TODO comments. 
(12) Done.
(13) I can create a fixed expected results as CSV files in this PR and Mike can resolve issues with R port in a separate PR.
(14) Done.

ad 2) ConvolutionOp->parseInput->extractValue throws an exception if its not a LiteralOp. Could we simply return -1 instead to make it robust enough to tolerate variables during compilation?

ad 3) The issue is that these "estimates" are propagated to dim1/dim2/nnz during refreshSizeInformation, which will be used by the parent operations. Note that for example a sum(X!=0) is just rewritten to take the nnz. Similarly the dims need to be correct, otherwise certain rewrites would be invalid too. If you cannot exactly infer these stats, please use the MemoTable and worst-case estimates.

ad 4) It would be great if we could move the handling of default parameters, and valid parameter names (in exitFunctionCallAssignmentStatement) into our actual validate.

Update: The issue with the R tests is indeed due to the port from DML -> R involving different R semantics.  

By default, R works with matrices in a column-wise manner, i.e., shaping a vector into a matrix will do so in a column wise manner:

``` r
> x = matrix(1:8, 2, 4)
> x
     [,1] [,2] [,3] [,4]
[1,]    1    3    5    7
[2,]    2    4    6    8
```

There is a `byrow` boolean flag to the `matrix(...)` that can be set to `TRUE` to enable a row-wise treatment:

``` r
> x = matrix(1:8, 2, 4, byrow=TRUE)
> x
     [,1] [,2] [,3] [,4]
[1,]    1    2    3    4
[2,]    5    6    7    8
```

**However**, this row-wise treatment is _not_ applied when unrolling a matrix back into a vector, regardless of the flag:

``` r
> matrix(x, 1, 8)
     [,1] [,2] [,3] [,4] [,5] [,6] [,7] [,8]
[1,]    1    5    2    6    3    7    4    8
> matrix(x, 1, 8, byrow=TRUE)
     [,1] [,2] [,3] [,4] [,5] [,6] [,7] [,8]
[1,]    1    5    2    6    3    7    4    8
```

Therefore, in R, we have to transpose the matrix first, and then unroll into a vector:

``` r
> matrix(t(x), 1, 8)
     [,1] [,2] [,3] [,4] [,5] [,6] [,7] [,8]
```

Note that this isn't necessary in DML.

1) Simplifications: Could you please simplify the implementation of matrixBlockToBinaryBlockLongIndex to use mapToPair instead of mapPartitionsToPair as you don't need the full partition scope here. Also please use the existing util functions for getBlockIndex and getIndexInBlock instead of creating replicas of these functions (e.g., in FrameRDDConverterUtils, FrameReblockBuffer).

thanks for the cleaned up pull request - @niketanpansare . Here are a couple of comments to further improve the current status:

1) Hop: Keeping the separate hop is ok for isolation, but we need to be aware that this hop then needs to be treated separately in the rewrites e.g., simplify agg over reorg. If you'd like to keep this hop, please remove the state that is just used locally (because it might confuse people why this status is not part of deep copy and compare)

2) Operator Selection: Please force the execution type cp, otherwise it would fail to compile
if we are running against hadoop/spark execution modes.

3) Simplify Parser: Could we please keep the syntactic parsers (dml, pydml) free of builtin function names and specific parameters. Please, move the entire code to validate (if really needed during parsing, at least let's rework this to a call to the respective expressions)

4) Simplify MatrixObject: in clearReusableData, the _data member is always of type MatrixBlock - so there is no need for checks or casts.

5) Simplify MatrixBlock: Please move the map for reused objects out of MatrixBlock as you anyway use it only from your CP instruction. Also let's remove the references from MatrixBlock to Statistics (having the map outside of matrixblock would simplify this too). Furthermore, you might want to think about a new operator type and methods in matrix block to surface the calls to LibMatrixDNN such that all operations are callable directly on the matrix block object.

6) Correctness Runtime NNZ Maintenance: You explicitly set outputBlock.setNonZeros(numRows \* numCols) during setup of the output blocks. This is incorrect if not all cells are represented in the output (not matter if dense or not) and if your operations call a set/get which internally increments the nnz too.

7) Correctness LibMatrixDNN: In doPoolingBackward you use double maxVal = Double.MIN_VALUE; However, this is incorrect in the presence of negative values. Please use -Double.MAX_VALUE (note that Double.MIN_VALUE is the smallest double magnitude not the minimal value). Also, it would be good to use the threads as passed into the runtime, without additional calls to OptimizerUtils.

8) Cleanup Tests: The calls to bHM.clear() in finalize are unnecessary as these maps are fully garbage collected.

9) Code Style: Finally, there are some minor code style issues. First, please use auto-boxing instead of explicit new Integer(val) whenever possible. Second, don't unnecessarily separate declaration and value assignment (e.g., params in ConvolutionCPInstruction). Third, please remove commented code.
Great, thanks @mboehm7 & @asurve!

@mboehm7 I looked into this more.  It turns out that access to the JVM SQLContext has always been officially exposed via `sqlContext._ssql_ctx` (as far back as 1.0).  However, we have been using an unofficial variable, `sqlContext._scala_SQLContext`, which has been renamed in 2.0.  So, luckily, this change will give us proper backward (and hopefully future) compatibility.

From discussions with a couple Python developers, this sounds like the best course to take WRT indexing.

@dusenberrymw Does slicing mirror the behavior of Python?

Yeah the slicing is correct as well: lower indices are inclusive, and upper indices are exclusive. Note that the upper bounds were already correctly exclusive in PyDML prior to this PR, and this just fixes the indices to be 0-based.
Also, I have some plans to improve the syntax for slicing as well to be closer to NumPy syntax.  It should be mostly cosmetic at the grammar level.
Thank you @dusenberrymw. The closer we mimic Python syntax, the easier it will be for Python developers to use PyDML.
LGTM.
LGTM.

To expand on the slicing aspect a bit, the slicing correctly uses inclusive lower and exclusive upper bounds.  However, a really useful piece of slicing syntax we are currently missing from PyDML is the ability to have implicit lower or upper bounds, i.e., `X[:3,]` should return all rows up to (but not including) 3.  This means that the implicit lower bound is 0.  Similarly, `X[2:,]` should return all rows starting at row 2 (0-based), which implies that the upper bound is equal to the number of rows of X.
I will merge this. This is a documentation fix for a typo most likely introduced by myself.
I've created [SYSTEMML-676](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/SYSTEMML-676) to track the slicing improvements.

just to provide some history here: at one point we supported implicit lower and upper bounds, but removed it because (1) it is invalid R (1:3 is a shorthand for sequence, which is undefined with missing lower/upper bounds), and (2) because we cannot compile valid execution plans in case of unknown input size. However, meanwhile (with dynamic recompilation), the latter problem can be mitigated with additional runtime changes (e.g., for forced CP execution w/o recompile).
